column1: Before 15 March 2021, will there be a lethal confrontation between the national military forces of Iran and the United States either in Iran or at sea?
column6: ['Foreign Policy', 'Security and Conflict']

Comments: Incremental adjustment down. The Times of Israel, 03/14/21, 'Israeli officials said to push calmer waters with Iran after alleged ship blasts': https://www.timesofisrael.com/israeli-officials-said-to-push-calmer-waters-with-iran-after-alleged-ship-blasts/ 'With a new administration in Washington that is still forming policy and engaging in ongoing indirect diplomacy with Iran to save the faltering 2015 nuclear deal, aggressive action would not be the right course, one official advised.'
It's quite not likely to have lethal confrontation currently with the pandemic.

It is 0 because there are just 2 days left for the specific question (deadline, territory of attack). However, the chances are high in the short-medium term as per the recent attacks in Iraq forces suspected to be Iran. The US has restrained so far but along with other foreign ministers, issued a statement condemning the 20 Feb attack. https://www.arabnews.com/node/1814131/middle-east
Pretty close to March 15.

Confrontation between US and Iran tends to occur out of Iranian space. E.g. Iraq (Soleimani) and recent retaliations by Iran against US Forces (February Iranian ballistic missile attack on Al Asad Airbase in Iraq). Retaliation by the US may be likely via drone strikes. But, strikes may be against Iranian militia within Iraq. A confrontation between Israel and Iran seems more likely at this time given Abraham Accord (https://thediplomat.com/2021/03/israel-iran-and-china-us-middle-east-relations/ )
U.S. attacked Iran backed forces in Syria, in Feb., but pretty close to March 15 now.
No current talks of violence
6 days left - dialing down.
They are trying to get back to the nuclear deal started and then stoped by trump administration. No country wants a war with the pandemic still at the forefront.
Deadline is approaching quickly. Reducing to zero.

I think there is a possibility but unlikely. Israel has been suspected of carrying out assassinations within Iran. There would most likely be U.S. Military strikes against Iranian backed militias in Iraq and Syria. President Biden authorized attacks on Iranian back militias in Syria on February 26 to prevent further attacks on US troops operating in Iraq and Syria. President Biden said during his campaign that he wants to reenter the 2015 Iran Nuclear Agreement that President Trump withdrew from. It would be difficult to continue nuclear talks with Iran if the threat of war was on the horizon. After President Trump ordered General Qasem Soleimani’s assassination, Iran’s Revolutionary Guard sent a retaliatory rocket attack against Al-Asad Air Base and base outside Irbil holding American troops in Iraq. Iran warned Iraq the attack was coming to prevent Iraqi deaths claiming they were only targeting the Americans in retaliation but also warned American allies their bases could be targeted as well. Afterwards Iranian authorities gave mixed messages: Iran’s Supreme Leader Ayatollah Khamenei and Iran’s President Hassan Rouhani both claimed Iran’s “final answer would be to kick all US forces out of the region”. Iran’s Defense Minister Amir Hatami said, “Iran’s response to any US retaliation would be proportional to US actions.” Iran’s Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif claimed “the attack was in self defense and denied seeking to escalate the situation into war.” If the US wants any agreement with Iran it will not initiate any direct military response unless it is to deter direct attacks against the United States. Initiating direct military attacks against Iran would also worsen American relationships with China and Russia since they are both Iranian allies. If Iran took unprovoked military actions against the United States it would lose its stance on the world stage that it wants to reengage with diplomacy. It could also lead to Iran’s isolation on the world stage, could see more economic sanctions, and could see other American allies, join in military retaliation. After Iran’s retaliatory attacks, UK’s Prime Minister Boris Johnson warned Iran not to repeat any reckless or dangerous attacks, and Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said Israel would strike back hard against any attacks.

There is a slim chance that a lethal confrontation will occur. Tensions are high right now between Iran and the United States. B-52s have just recently flown over Iran as a warning from the U.S (U.S. News, 2021). Due to there only being a little more than a week to go there is a small chance that a lethal confrontation will occur.

It is unlikely that a lethal confrontation between national military forces will occur. Recent displays of violence cannot be interpreted as trends. While minor instances may occur, proxy forces are much more likely to sustain casualties, and this question does not seem to cover mercenaries/state supported terrorist organizations.
Probability: 1%

With 8 days left until this deadline, it's less likely that a lethal confrontation will occur in that small of a window. However, I think it is likely the Iranian forces will attack US bases in the area again in the near future.

I feel as though this would be more likely to happen later in the future, however with only 8 days left until the deadline, it's more unlikely. There has not been any recent leads to assume that a lethal confrontation between Iran and the U.S will occur just next week. However, with Biden's recent airstrike and previous tensions between the U.S and Iran, I wouldn't make this a 0% chance in happening.

Such an event is not unlikely, but with only 8 days left until the deadline, there is not a necessarily high probability of a lethal confrontation between the national military forces of Iran and the United States. I am not predicting this to be close to 0% though because there is an active ‘tit-for-tat’ happening between the US and Iran.

Comments: Seeing increasing volatility in region attributed to surrogates. Affirming forecast. The Jerusalem Post, 03/07/21, 'Hijacking, riots and explosions: Iran’s regime tested amid tensions': https://www.jpost.com/middle-east/hijacking-riots-and-explosions-irans-regime-tested-amid-tensions-661194 Clips from JP article: 'The increase in arrests of Kurds by the IRGC is part of the same pattern in Baluchistan and in Ahvaz. It is not like these three incidents are all just random. In each area, the corps has usurped the powers of the government to conduct most of Iran’s operations. In each place, it is also clear that unrest is boiling beneath the surface. The face that Iran tries to project beyond its borders, of power and strength, belies a very real series of problems closer to home. The overall context is that Iran is also suffering from COVID-19 and is implementing various travel regulations and trying to cope with continued sanctions. Although it says its indigenous industry can keep up with the challenges, it has invested heavily in weapons, such as ballistic missiles, and neglects some industries at home.' The Daily Sabah, 03/07/21, 'Iran-backed militia leader threatens to take up arms against Turkey': https://www.dailysabah.com/politics/war-on-terror/iran-backed-militia-leader-threatens-to-take-up-arms-against-turkey Al-Jazeera, 03/05/21, 'Gantz says Israel has list of Iran-backed targets ready to strike': https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2021/3/5/gantz-says-israel-has-list-of-iran-backed-targets-ready-to-strike

With less than 10 days remaining in the timeline of this prediction, and as things continue as they have in the last two months, there is less and less likelihood that a lethal confrontation will happen by 15 March, 2021.

Iran and the US seem to be employing their rockets in a game of tit for tat Iran retaliated for Biden's rocket strike in Syria with an attack on an Iraqi air base where American soldiers were known to be. Tensions are high and will likely continue to be high as they have been. However, at the rate things are going right now, I don't think that this game will escalate to lethal confrontation in the next 9 days. The possibility is not 0%, though, in my opinion considering the US's willingness to use projectile weapons in these confrontations.

In my assessment, there is a very low chance of lethal confrontation occurring between national military forces of Iran and the United States either in Iran or at Sea. This is due to numerous factors. For one, Iran and the United States are not formally at war. Even with the two being at war, this scenario would still be somewhat unlikely, as non-combat deaths make up more than 70% of all deaths that the US military has recently suffered (Congressional Research Service, 2020). This happening within the next week in a half is highly unlikely, which is why I gave this scenario a 1% likelihood.
Both sides will continue to compete through proxies. Pres.Biden will not be taking further offensive actions without Congressional approval. See Senator Tim Kaine.

Tensions don't seem to be letting up anytime soon, especially with the recent rocket strikes and retaliatory strikes by the US in Syria. While I don't think it will escalate much more in the 9 days remaining-there is a chance that something will happen that leads to a fatality, especially in the "tit for tat" game that Iran is playing with the United States.

Relations between the U.S. and Iran are still severe. A deadly encounter between each side's national military forces could result in casualties. Even Though there is tension between the two countries there is most likely a 0% chance for a confrontation to occur by March 15th.

While there continues to be tensions between the U.S. and Iran, particularly within the borders of Iraq and Iran-backed militia’s launching rocket attacks at bases housing U.S. troops (https://www.politico.com/news/2021/03/04/iran-group-responsible-iraq-attack-473618) as well as the U.S. launching airstrikes against Iran-backed militia in Syria on February 15, 2021 (https://www.politico.com/news/2021/03/04/iran-group-responsible-iraq-attack-473618). The likelihood of a lethal confrontation between the national military forces of Iran and the U.S. is highly unlikely. There is likely to be continued tension and confrontations both within Syria and Iraq but also at sea, yet the likelihood of a deadly confrontation would likely be as a result of a miscalculation or misstep as the any death of a U.S. military member by an Iranian military member would likely result in a broader campaign against Iran by the U.S. This is not in Iran’s best interest and it would be far better for Iran to continue to support militia’s and proxy groups that can wage more open attacks against U.S. interests in the region.
time is running out
It is currently March 4th and there appears to be no news of rising tensions.

On February 15th, 2021, pro-Iran militias fired rockets at a U.S. airbase in Iraq’s Kurdistan region, injuring 9 (including Americans) and killing 1 (foreign civilian contractor). Five days later, on February 20th, Balad Airbase in Iraq's Saladin Governorate was targeted by another rocket attack. A South African civilian contractor working for the U.S. was injured in the attack. In response to the Erbil attack, President Biden ordered airstrikes against Kata'ib Hezbollah facilities in Syria on February 26th. The attack may have killed over a dozen people/militants. The most recent attack occurred on March 3rd, when Al Asad air base in Iraq – housing U.S. and collation troops – were targeted by a rocket attack. A U.S. civilian contractor suffered a heart attack during the strike and died.

Given that the deadline for this prediction is in less than two weeks, I believe that the likelihood that there will be a lethal confrontation between the national military forces of Iran and the U.S. either in Iran or at sea depends on whether there are indicators of an immediate conflict or attack. Tensions between the US and Iran definitely rose during Trump's time in office, stemming from actions such as withdrawing the US from the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA) in 2018 and the assassination of Qasem Soleimani in 2020. With the new administration, many are hoping for a shift in dynamic between the two countries; however, with the Biden administration joining European partners in an effort to begin talks with Iran for the first time in several years to settle differences and revive the 2015 nuclear deal, as well as the recent attacks on US bases in the Middle East and Biden's decision to strike Iranian-linked groups in Syria in late February, it is uncertain whether relations between the US and Iran will worsen or better in the following months. But the US and Iran are in a very precarious situation right now, with both sides avoiding a direct military confrontation, instead attacking each other through the US imposing economic sanctions, Iran targeting US allies (such as Saudi Arabia and Israel), and both engaging in conflict through Iranian-backed proxy forces (like Ketaib Hezbollah). These conflicts have mostly occurred in other countries, specifically Iraq, making it even less likely that there will be a confrontation between the two within Iran or at sea. If any lethal confrontation were to occur in the next two weeks, it will be an attack on a US base by Iran-backed militants or a US strike against Iranian proxies, but there is a very low chance that there will be a lethal military confrontation between the national military forces of Iran and the United States military either in Iran or at sea. However, given the current delicate environment, I will never say never, so I am giving a 1% likelihood of occurrence.
Biden appears to wish to resolve the issue, albeit perhaps in the model of JCPOA "plus". I am updating mainly though only to factor for elapsed time as the basic factors seem pretty much the same.
Iran has been flexing its military forces and seems agitated by U.S. relations currently, but the likelihood of a fatal confrontation remains low.

Wednesday, March 3rd, Ain al-Asad air base came under attack. No uniformed U.S. troops were injured however it will be interesting to see how this plays out. This attack comes after the US launched a strike on Iranian-backed militia targets in Syria. This type of tit-for-tat almost led Iran and the U.S to the brink of war last year

I think there is a very very small chance that Biden would initiate a confrontation between Iran and the United States. He created a large plan for his first 100 days, that is mainly centered around decreasing COVID-19 numbers. It would be too much to deal with Before March 15, 2021. I do think that it is a likely possibility that Biden would choose to use nuclear weapons on Iran in the future.
Biden unlikely to raise tensions with Iran during his first 100 days.

Virtually no chance of conflict on Iranian soil. With both US and Iran both focused on domestic issues in the mains, only a small outlier chance of a seaborne conflict. The US has a large military presence in the countries neighbouring Iran's southern borders. The US has very recently sent a 3rd warship into the Black Sea to the north of Iran, in a measure to step up it's military presence in the region. Iran is heavily outgunned by US forces surrounding Iran in the region.

Seeing as how the deadline for this prediction is in less than two weeks, there would need to be indicators of an imminent attack for there to be any likelihood of this happening. Iran has recently refused offers from the European Union to engage the United States directly in talks regarding a rejoining of the Joint Cooperative Plan of Action, levying a requirement for the US to alleviate economic sanctions prior to such a conversation. Some believe Iran is looking for an opportunity to avenge the January 2020 assassination of General Qasem Soleimani, with Iranian judiciary chief Ebrahim Raisi going as far as to say their revenge is “close at hand” during a meeting with Faiq Zidan, Head of the Iraqi Supreme Judicial Council in Baghdad. If Iran were to conduct an attack against US forces on land, it would likely continue to leverage a proxy-force such as the Kataib Hezbollah as they have in the past, reducing the chances the US would retaliate with an attack across the Iranian border. Kayhan, a hardline Iranian media outlet, recently cited unnamed “military experts” in crediting Iran with an attack on the MV Helios Ray, an Israeli vehicle carrier, off the coast of Oman, indicating probable Iranian capability and intent to execute such attacks against perceived threats. The US Naval Institute indicated that as of 1 March 2021, the Makin Island Amphibious Ready Group (ARG) is currently located in the Persian Gulf, providing a possible, albeit incredibly well-defended, target for a potential attack such as seen with the MV Helios Ray. Two factors inhibit this option for Iran; first the attack would be highly unlikely to be successful against a large group of US naval ships sure to be on alert in their current geographic location and secondly the political ramifications Iran would suffer if their direct involvement were discovered could see the loss of support from the European Union, causing further economic hardships for the country. Based on this information, I cannot completely rule out the chances of either the US or the Iranian Revolutionary Guard Corps suffering a fatality at sea over the next two weeks, but it is extremely unlikely. Due to the short suspense for this forecast and the significantly remote chance of this occurring, I will grant a 1% chance this may occur in the next two weeks and a 99% chance that any conflict, if it does occur, will continue through proxy-forces in Iraq and/or Syria.
short time frame, pandemic focused right now
With the current tension between Syria and the USA, it is not likely they would extend hostilities to Iran.
Changing to the crowd forecast because with 13 days left, the chance is remote.

A conflict may happen due to the provoking by any of the two sides, by any one of the parties who belong to the two sides. US is going slow in its announcement to return to the nuclear treaty between the two sides. It may not start any conflict. Iran, on the other hand, is facing hardships due to the pandemic, sanctions and pressure is increasing from within. Iran has also avowed to take action against the killing of its military leader. Iran is also due for a presidential election in June. A hardliner within may want to initiate a conflict to divert the ongoing problems or preparation for the election. However, the chances of Iran initiating a conflict may be very remote in the near future. There may also be conflict initiated by a third party who may not to see improving relationship between US-Iran.
I don't expect anything to happen with military forces in such a short time frame
Biden seems to be following in Obama's footsteps, so drone strikes could possibly be in Iran's future.
I chose this because I think there is a very low chance that this will happen but it is a possibility that Iran would feel the need to retaliate in some way.
Upping to 10% - still remote, but the US bombing of Iranian-backed militias in Syria is concerning. (https://us.cnn.com/2021/02/25/politics/us-iraq-iran/index.html)
https://us.cnn.com/2021/02/25/politics/us-iraq-iran/index.html

Very little chance, especially with a Biden Presidency. Tensions have died down since the killing of Qassem Soleimani. The nuclear deal and lifting of sanctions is an "olive branch" but there's some relationship repairing that both sides are interested in. (https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-02-19/u-s-iran-standoff-shows-difficulty-of-salvaging-nuclear-deal.) Barring something we don't already know I'll say the chances are remote, although never 0.
Only by accident....

Potential for accidental clash at sea which results in a fatality, particularly if both sides are attempting to exert influence ahead of nuclear talks. Potential for elements of the IRGC to seek to derail talks. Limited time frame from assessment (20 days), place this at the lowest possible risk.

Comments: Black swan event(s) perpetrated by Israeli or Iranian hardliners to derail diplomatic efforts keep me at my current forecast. President Biden offered to come to the table to discuss a nuclear deal with Iran. The United States would like to open negotiations with Iran that includes other world powers who participated in the JCPOA talks. The Biden Administration also reversed sanctions on Iran and eased travel restrictions of Iranian diplomats. These are large signals to Iran that the United States would like to work together. Additionally, Iran has been requesting an ease on the sanctions imposed by the United States for some time now. With these events unfolding, the likelihood of there being a lethal confrontation between Iran and the United States plummeted.

1) The U.S. has removed its Carrier Strike Group from the region. This decreases the military tension in the region. While it could be argued that now is the time for Iran to "kill" a U.S. Navy sailor because the U.S. is not in a position to respond, that just really isn't the case. There are still plenty of US Navy assets in the region that could respond, as well as US Air Force that could strike the Iranian military.

Decreasing due to NATO’s decision to increase number of troops in Iraq ( https://www.defense.gov/Explore/News/Article/Article/2507564/nato-defense-leaders-agree-to-increase-iraqi-mission-defer-decision-on-afghanis/). This will likely regarded as an adequate response to Thursday’s attack by Iranian-backed militia (https://news.google.com/articles/CAIiEN7eh9qWe19oGuMCBI7W_R8qGAgEKg8IACoHCAowjtSUCjC30XQw_qe5AQ?hl=en-US&gl=US&ceid=US%3Aen). Any direct attack on Iran would further impede Biden’s ability to negotiate with Iran.
US has expressed interest in renewing talks with Iran on denuclearization. This will likely further decrease the risk of a lethal confrontation between the two nations.

Adjusting up due to recent news from Iraq (https://www.newsweek.com/us-base-attack-forces-joe-biden-juggle-retaliation-iran-nuclear-deal-hopes-1569887). Waiting for the decision of the Wed-Thurs NATO conference.
Refreshing the forecast. While time has indeed elapsed that has not changed the underlying calculation.

Upon further research, I have come to the conclusion that this is a classic example of the chicken game. Both parties need to negotiate, as Iran needs the sanctions to be lifted, and the United States wants to prevent Iran from pursuing nuclear arms development. (https://news.cgtn.com/news/2021-02-14/Iran-vs-U-S-Who-will-blink-first--XQCMSztMvS/index.html). But the biggest hurdle is the potential damage to the country's image. If either country states that it wants to start negotiations it will lose face, and appear as the weaker of the two powers. With this in mind as with the chicken game, there are four outcomes. Two of them involve either power wanting to negotiate, the other involves both countries agreeing to negotiate and the final one is both countries refuse to negotiate and this would lead to an escalation. Especially with the United States' seizure of Iranian oil(https://www.aljazeera.com/economy/2021/2/15/tehran-calls-us-seizure-of-iranian-oil-an-act-of-piracy), this may lead to an accidental or purposeful lethal confrontation. Therefore I predict that there is a 25% chance of a lethal confrontation.
in case Iran is culpable for attacks yesterday in Iraq and US send a missile into Iran

He also said he believes the new administration of US President Joe Biden has independence and will not cater to Israel like his predecessor Donald Trump. Kochavi’s remarks were also seen as a threat to the Biden administration that has said it wants to restore the 2015 nuclear deal Tehran signed with world powers.'
This question is most likely about the chances of an unexpected or unintentional confrontation more than an intentional one from either the Iranian or US side.
Update to previous forecast based on time remaining.
Iran will most take a wait-and-see approach to determine what the new US administration plans to do. So only if by accident something happens.
Closing date coming up
Similar rationale as original forecast, slight risk due to US exploring Saudi bases as @IVCoffeePlz, but highly unlikely.
the closing'date is near

Although tensions were elevated in the beginning of the year in the wake of the anniversary of Soleimani's death, activity remained short of military action. With the Biden administration now in office and open communication with Iran, military use of force in a lethal confrontation seems highly unlikely. Secretary of State Blinken has already been in talks with Iran over lifting the current sanctions. This line of communication signals a willingness to engage on the diplomatic front prior to resorting to military force. Additionally, President Biden has nominated the lead negotiator from the JCPOA (Iran Nuclear Deal) for Deputy Secretary of State. This experience and established relationships with Iran's leadership indicates more engagement on the diplomatic front before a military confrontation.
Unlikely
I'll adjusted up one percentage point for this article here: https://www.militarytimes.com/news/your-military/2021/01/26/us-exploring-new-bases-in-saudi-arabia-amid-iran-tensions/

adjusting my prediction down a bit now seems like the worst of the tension has evaporated with the inauguration of the new U.S. president. https://www.defenseone.com/threats/2021/01/war-avoided-biden-brings-opportunity-new-iran-relations-top-general-says/171594/ as opposed to pre 20 Jan https://apnews.com/article/joe-biden-donald-trump-iran-middle-east-baghdad-7532d20c40b9d1240c77f26f621d2902

I can find no instances of a lethal confrontation between U.S. and Iranian military forces inside Iran or at sea since at least the 1979 Iranian Revolution. Conflict between Iranian proxy forces (primarily Kata’ib Hezbollah) and U.S. military forces in Iraq occurs several times each year. However, retaliatory strikes remain confined to forces stationed inside Iraq. Iran also routinely seizes and sabotages foreign ships transiting the Persian Gulf. However, I found no evidence of Iran targeting U.S. military or civilian vessels. In 2019, Iran did shoot-down a U.S. RQ-4 flying near its border, however, this does not qualify as a “lethal” confrontation as the RQ-4 is unmanned. Both the U.S. and Iran seem to recognize that attacking one another’s forces inside Iran or at sea is a significant escalation neither side is willing to make.

With the change in administration, Iran perceives less of a maximum pressure and aggressive posture from United States. While violence in Iraq and Syria continues, in particular Israel action against potential Iranian forces in Syria, the likelihood of US-Iran conflict is low. More likely potentially an attack or fatalities from 'proxies', Israel fighter shot down, or perhaps a Iranian aligned militia soldier fatality which will be difficult to tie directly to Iran.

Comments: Posturing continues between Gulf principals. IL to 'wait-and-see'. Haaretz, 01/24/21, 'Analysis | As Biden Pushes Iran Nuclear Deal, Israel Puts Military Option Back on the Table - Israel sees the previous agreement as too weak, and worries that the Biden administration will not be tough enough during future negotiations with Iran': https://www.haaretz.com/us-news/.premium-with-iran-nuclear-deal-likely-israel-puts-all-options-back-on-the-table-1.9475652 Al-Jazeera, 01/19/21, 'Iran holds fifth military drill in two weeks amid tension with US - Iran showcases special forces, helicopters and tanks after the US flies B-52 bombers over the Middle East again': https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2021/1/19/irans-army-holds-war-games-again-after-us-flies-bombers
Base rate very low...Operation Praying Mantis in the 1980s is about all the comes to mind...timeline is short...geographic scope is limited to Iran or sea, so not Iraq or Syria or Yemen, etc.

Surely the Iranians will want to test an administration they feel is ready to facilitate their end-goal of achieving a nuclear weapon. However, the Iranians are rational and know being at fault for loss of American lives derails that desired end-state.
Within President Biden's first 100 days - no. Beyond that - it depends.
Not with Biden taking the helm

I agree with other forecasters that both sides are looking to "normalize" relations during the Biden administration. However, careful analysis might lead one to believe that US/Iranian relations have been anything but normal over the years (U.S. meddling in Tehran, Iran-Contra, Airliners shot down by mistake by both sides, drone shot down, decapitation strike on a top general, and the list goes on...). All that said, lethal strikes on opposing military forces are still extremely rare...add in that President-Elect Biden has said his administration intends to reenergize the nuclear deal, and I believe tensions will remain cool in the near term. I still give the chances of a lethal encounter a 2% possibility (accounting for accidental miscalculations).

Adapted/reposted from team discussion. There are multiple factors that make it appear that a lethal confrontation is becoming less likely, but there are also numerous factors that seem to be maintaining at least that possibility. On the morning of 17 Jan alone, there are numerous reports of strain between Iran and foreign powers regarding its nuclear program which includes a tweet from Iran’s foreign minister accusing France of destabilizing the region. Additionally, as Iran apparently redoubles its nuclear efforts its concerns about a strike are evident, requesting that the IAEA not publish “details” of its programs. This backdrop combined with its latest missile test leads me to believe that there is no discernible downward trend in tension.

Reduced as now only a limited chance of Trump being able to order preemptive actions before Jan 20. Seems unlikely that Iran will want to provoke Biden early in presidency. Always risks of shifts because of Saudi, accidents etc
Currently a wait and see approach with the new US government.

The base rate for this class of events is low. If we take the base rate from last year (which is probably higher than average over time) of one chance in 12 that a lethal confrontation between IR and US national military forces takes place in a given month, you get about a 16% chance (8% x 2 months) that a lethal confrontation would occur between now (15 jan) and 15 March. I thought this base rate would be too high relative to the average over time, but just researching a little, it seems that US strikes have targeted IR troops in Syria over the past few years, so it might not be that much higher than the post-9/11 average. The base rate also should be moderated by the many factors the crowd has pointed out already, some of which nudge the probability upward and some downward: increased US presence in Gulf at present (up); Iranian exercises in Gulf upcoming (up); legislative determination to ramp up nuclear production (up); a new administration (down); promise for a reentry/renegotiation of the JCPOA (down); economic problems internally (down); COVID preoccupation (down). The myriad particular factors almost end in a wash but my gut says 16% is too high to be reasonable, so dropping down to 12% to allow for unintended lethality (accidents, troops acting without authorization) and the desire to create favorable relations for a new US administration.

Outside View: if we take the national military force to mean the recognized and uniformed forces of Iran (which I will because it will be too hard to ID any advisors to Iraqi insurgent groups) the percentage drops markedly. The last armed confrontation was the January 2020 missile strike on Solemani and the retaliatory strikes on US bases, prior to that the RQ-4 shoot down in June 2019. Before that there have been no recent lethal actions between the two states. set the scope at Jan 2019 leads to 5% chance per month, leading 2.5 % for the next two weeks.

The anniversary would have been the most likely time for reprisal, and Iran chose to issue the arrest warrant against an outgoing President (in a lame-duck period) this appears to be more of a signal to the incoming President as to how Iran will view any similar targeted action in the future. I think the message is that the next administration has an opportunity to repair relations (in some way) as the warrant and charges are against an outgoing politician. If lethal confrontations occur, I suspect they will be from a further sanctioning that could occur if Iraq presses the Biden administration or tests their resolve for Iranian denuclearization.

The new administration is going to look to defuse the current tensions with Iran. Additionally, Iran will likely welcome any overtures made by the U.S. that reduce some of the economic sanctions Iran faces from the U.S. Whether or not this remains the case beyond March 2021 is anyone's guess, but in the near-term, both parties seem to desire a reduction in tension. Furthermore, both countries are facing domestic issues that would only be exacerbated by the threat or engagement of military hostiliites.

While there is daily contact between Iranian naval forces and the US Navy throughout the Arabian Gulf region, I cannot recall a time in the last 5-10 years that those confrontations have resulted in the death of a servicemember from either nation. Such an occurrence would probably result in a significant escalation in the region, so it is not in either nation's interest to have such an event occur. Both nations seem to favor proxy warfare or engaging one another in a "perceived" neutral location, e.g. Iraq or Yemen. As someone who has spent months onboard a US Navy ship in the region, the near-daily contact between the forces and the tensions that exist means that the probability cannot be reduced too low.

As the anniversary of the Soleimani strike has come and gone with little movement on Iran's part it is hard to believe that there will be an intentional violent confrontation. Instead, despite US domestic issues, Iran seems to be pursuing a more legalistic approach to the the US by issuing arrest warrants, as well as likely inciting Iraq to the do the same. This approach is more beneficial to the Iranian regime as it likely expects the incoming Biden administration to move back towards the JCPOA. If Iran inflames tensions and it results in death(s), a return to the deal will become more unlikely. With the tensions in the region lethal confrontations remain possible, but both sides have shown a willingness to avoid death even when discord climaxes.

So, a clash within the next two months (a pretty short time period) between Iran and the U.S. as defined by the question would be unwise for both, but especially for Iran, which has a lot to gain or loose from a less antagonistic American policy shift under a Joseph Biden administration. This not least relating to a return to the JCPOA or something similar. Iran will of course talk tough, but even statements from The Supreme Leader point further towards a pause to see what Biden will do (see AP link in question details).

Always non-zero, especially when the two militaries (navies) are in daily contact. Nevertheless, but as this is specifically in Iran (not Syria or Iraq) or at sea and if we assume Obama's focus on a deal with Iran presages a similar policy under Biden and that Iran (both the government and IRGC) will already in some form of communication with Biden's team, it would take a rapid escalation for a calculated (as opposed to accidental) confrontation leading to a fatality.
